"While I don't agree with prosecutors reading emails it appears most people don't seem to care anymore with Google, Facebook and others tracking everything people write, post, etc."

Privacy restrictions on government have special importance because government is uniquely empowered to use force and incarceration to deny individuals liberty, potentially take their life in case of capital crimes, and take property.
While ideally government would be altruistic, in reality it is also political and run by people. The special powers warrant special restrictions.

I agree that the ACLU is focused on too many issues that technology is quickly outdating, such as privacy that will be de facto impossible when private companies hold so much data yet the ACLU continues to bemoan the gov't excesses at every turn.  As a year long volunteer at my local chapter, no college credit or any kind of credit, I am a supporter just disagree with them lately.

Consider the Electronic Frontier Foundation at: www.eff.org
They are far more attuned to issues involving technology, which the ALCU is still getting up to speed on. Both organizations work together on many issues, although the focus of each differs.

These days it appears privacy doesn't appear to exist anymore. While I don't agree with prosecutors reading emails it appears most people don't seem to care anymore with Google, Facebook and others tracking everything people write, post, etc.

The ACLU may find itself like Queen Mab in the Merlin movies as it no longer exists because people don't believe in it anymore. What was a major concern in the recent past appears to be just being shrugged off by Gen-X and the Millennials as they expect this.

In the Pacific Northwest we have a white supremacist Joey Petersen who with another killed his parents and two other people. The prosecutors have a pretty much an open and shut case, the only question on the table was the death penalty. The prosecutors opened privileged letters between him and his lawyers.

It makes me wonder if the prosecutors these days doubt their abilities or they are willing to do everything they can to win their case. Guaranteeing the ability of someone under arrest to communicate with their lawyer(s) in confidentially should be paramount but that doesn't appear to be the case anymore.

I'm not sure if it ever was truly universally observed but there was a time people thought it was a right for those arrested.

The criminal bar members I know all assume - correctly I believe - that police, prosecutors and custody officers read or listen to all attorney-client communications.  They may say they don't, but they could if they wanted to, and I suspect most of them want to.  I would also suspect, without any proof, that a significant percentage of attorney-client interview rooms in jails and prisons contain hidden microphones which can be used by prosecutors and police to listen in on attorney-client conversations, and with pin hole cameras available to virtually everyone, I assume they also have cameras.  The best advice I have heard given to a criminal suspect by his attorney was to "pretend like you are a deaf-mute" except to say "yes" or "no" to the custody officers.  That way your cell mate - in exchange for a deal with the prosecutor for a reduced sentence on his 30 year felony term - will not miraculously overhear you confess to shooting Abraham Lincoln.

This is an absolutely egregious breach of A/C privilege.  CorrLinks should absolutely not be considered unprivileged, especially considering that most lawyers are really only readily accessible by email, with phone calls being infrequent and difficult and USPS being slow.  Wake up and smell the 21st century prosecutors!  Email is becoming a necessity for communication, and inmates are entitled to privileged communication with their counsel.  Lawyers must continue to make appeals based on this issue, until it can be settled the way the issue of unwarranted cell phone searches was by the Supreme Court--unanimously and with federal legal authority,

You see, here we are all thoughtful people, yet making broad generalizations about the relationships between race, crime, and income.  While there are many examples of such relationships, there are also notable examples of real places - right near NYC - where these relationships do not hold true.  This is one of the reasons NeighborhoodScout is useful. It reveals the true complexity of place and by doing so, helps break stereotypes.  I did a search for neighborhoods that have low crime, high income, and high % black population.  More than 700 neighborhoods in the US scored 'Very Good" to "Excellent" matches to those criteria.  Including neighborhoods in West Orange, NJ (eg: S Valley Rd at Tremont Ave), and Brooklyn, NY (eg: Avenue N at E 104th), neighborhoods in State Farm, VA and North Chicago, IL among others. The outlier places tell a story as useful to recognize as the more commonly recognized places.

I suspect that these services are attracted to some because it reduced the perceived uncertainty about the neighborhood. Most services miss major characteristics (like the home is in a 50 year flood plain) and all future expected changes. A major retail/residential project will start breaking ground soon in my neighborhood, no mention of this in any of these services. If the house for sale is near the project, as a buyer, I would want to know this.

Some of the statements are not even supported by the data. In one, my neighborhood is described as being dominated by Hipsters - sorry, the majority of households are African-Americans homeowners in their 40's to 60's with families. Based on this, I do worry about racial steering through these services.

Uncertainty breeds restrained investment, prompting focus on short-term, marginal strategies? Really?

Let's look at a country that we can agree has had a very tumultuous history: Germany. Didn't even exist until 1870! Right away, war with France. Next WW1, crazy inflation due to payment for those wars against France. WW2! That totally flattened the country. 1/3 sliced off. 1/3 of the rest taken by the Soviets. 12 million refugees flooded the shrunken nation. It was the country that knew if there was a war between the US and USSR it would most certainly be destroyed. When would it be unified? Never? How would they rebuild the nation? Make peace with Poland and France? All very uncertain.

They focused on long-term investment in education, infrastructure, and social welfare. This is also what they did in 1870. But for a few decades they forgot that long-term investment in education, infrastructure, and social welfare is a better bet than building huge armies to bomb everyone they can.

Now they have low unemployment, highly educated people who feel rather safe in health and wealth. Infrastructure that makes us look like we don't know what "engineer" means. People work regular hours with vacations. Govt runs healthcare at half the price we pay.

But we're the people spending our money on bombs. Not knowing when your country is going to start a trillion dollar war breeds uncertainty. That's the ultimate in regulatory uncertainty. Not increased funding of schools or food stamps.

When I was working with the DC office of whatever law firm I was with, I was involved in a transaction managed by Goldman Sachs to finance a coal transshipment port in Newport, Virginia. My firm was hired to approve the bonds being issued to finance the facility. It was a complicated deal with five coal companies with different credit ratings involved. The esteemed firm of King and Spalding from Atlanta represented Goldman. The Goldman representative was a young woman who was married to the son of Goldman’s chairman. We met at the offices of Cravath, a white shoe NYC firm, where most of the time the Goldman rep clipped recipes from journals while the lawyers negotiated. In retrospect she accomplished more than the lawyers did at the meetings.

E.F. Hutton was big in those days. “When E. F. Hutton talks, people listen.” Hutton is no longer around, due in large part to a scandal commonly known as “check-kiting.” Go here to learn about check-kiting: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Check_kiting. In short, it was a scam to allow Hutton to make money off of bad checks. After the scam was discovered, a King and Spalding lawyer, Judge Griffin Bell (who had been a US Court of Appeals Judge and who was Jimmy carter’s first Attorney General) was hired by Hutton to investigate the cash management practices of Hutton.

Another lawyer at King and Spalding I met during that time allowed how he read indentures backwards to proof them. That’s how nuts the legal profession is.

"On Monday, the Israeli military fired artillery rounds at Al Aqsa hospital in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza, claiming to target a cache of anti-tank missiles. Dr. Khalil Khattab, a surgeon, was operating on a patient when the first shell struck. He ran to the floors below to discover at least four dead and dozens of colleagues — doctors, nurses, orderlies and administrators — injured. The medical staff had become patients."

In terms of poverty, some of our students may be better off on paper but not in reality. It's one thing to be poor materially and another to be devoid of the intangible things. I'm sure there are many reasons why public education suffers here, but lowered expectations may be a symptom of a bigger problem.

p.s. And don't you be so naive as to believe that researchers consider all of the points raised by others. Mr. Schleicher is from a different country, which brings into question his ability to understand poverty in America vs. a country where healthcare and education are essentially free.
